Pretty good, large portion, pretty waitress, bad parking and poor atmosphere. I don't know if I'd go back. Maybe if I was really hungry and it boiled down to this place or the Cheba Hut.

I thought it would've been better because of all the awesome reviews and the hype I've heard from the great vine..but it wasn't all that. 

We tried about 4 - 5 different dishes to all share & every dish seemed bland - no seasonings & lacked that "homemade" taste they were advertising throughout the menu. We tried 1) French toast - was okay nothing special  2) biscuits & gravy - this was gross & we looove biscuits & gravy.. 3) Tiffany omelette- was okay interesting mix of shrimp, asparagus & hollandaise sauce 4) chicken fried steak - again very bland nothing special about this & we had bacon eggs and hash browns too and we just felt everything was consistently mediocre nothing really good or great..Oh and we also did the blueberry & peach cream muffins those were okay. Maybe my expectations were too high ? Or we didn't get the right things but we probably won't be returning.

I really like this breakfast/brunch spot!  Today was my 4th time here, and my 3rd time with my fianc.  The servers here are always friendly and you can tell that they get a lot of repeat business because nearly everyone around me whenever I've eaten there is a regular that the waitresses know by name.  Everyone there always seems cheerful and the quality of the food is excellent and always consistent every time I've been there.  

Today we received a real blessing!  We were enjoying our food when our server (this is the second time I've had this same server, and she is very sweet) came over and let us know that we were all taken care of and presented us with a brown paper bag that had a jar of their house made salsa in it as well!  She let us know that the owner (who had seated us) had taken care of our meal!  

I definitely recommend this place if you want good food and service from people who really care about their customers!  I have had the chorizo and eggs twice.  It is delicious, though some may find it too spicy (I love spicy food), and I recommend getting it with tortillas as their tortillas are also delicious.  I love their breakfast potatoes which are always crispy on the outside!  My fianc had the breakfast sandwich, which he thoroughly enjoyed.  We haven't tried anything off of the lunch menu, but I wouldn't expect it to be anything less than spectacular!
Great for breakfast/brunch! Delicious and hardy meals. We were served extremely fast and the atmosphere was fun.
Bleeping awesome Breakfast and lunches. Chorizo is made on site. I will make the 14 mile drive for their food. Good traditional American food. Service is great.

Harlows is a nice little breaky and lunch place in the heart of the Tempe college area. Its not in my normal 3 square mile radius so it took me forreeevver to finally come here after it being recommended by a good friend a ways back. 

I'm glad I finally made the trek. The place is fun, quirky and has this old 'grandmas' diner vibe with the spin of interesting by hanging collectible movie memorabilia and pictures on the walls. Nothing like drinking coffee out of those old porcelin shaply mugs that remind you of grandmas place. 

The staff was supa friendly and nice, and I have nothing bad to say about their tight shirts and yoga pants as the waitress staple. 

The food menu is carb driven.. At breakfast places I get omelettes because I eat pretty clean. The sides offered with my omelette were Toast, a muffin, or bagel and they wouldn't let me sub for fruit. So i waived my right and spent too much money on not nerely enough food. Furthermore, i didn't touch the potatoes on my plate... So I essentially pad $17 for 3 eggs, salsa and coffee. Wamp! #notimpressed

However, if you love a good comfort food breakfast... this is your place!

Ok let me start by saying I am a breakfast freak and relentlessly pursue new spots to eat breakfast.  I love eating, finding, reviewing and searching out new breakfast spots. 

I did not find this on any website to begin with.  I found this place on accident when i pulled into a parking lot to set my GPS.  I was about to leave and looked up to find the parking lot was full of cars.  This is always a good sign but I couldn't stop and eat right then so i made a note to come back.

Character:  This place has a ton of character and has been updated on the inside for some time but i really enjoy a place like this.  I'm sure it has a ton of locals it's hard to know going ur first time but everyone was very friendly including the waitresses and hostess.

Food: The food was good I had a breakfast burrito smothered with Pork Green Chile.  The boy had a bunny pancake with an egg.  It was good food that came very quick and hot.  I wish i could go back, consistency is a big deal but its back to Vegas tomorrow.

Coffee:  I don't like to see the bottom of my coffee cup when I'm at breakfast and they were quick to refill when it got low and they were always walking around with a pot of coffee.

Thank you Harlow's

Great breakfast! We came on a Sunday, and had to wait a good 25 minutes for a table. Certainly a good sign in any diner. We skipped their famous biscuits and gravy for other classic eggs and assorted sides. Service was great, food came out much faster than expected, and no mistakes in the five meals we ordered. Just remember no substitutions on any meals. And carry cash! Using our cards held up the line. Overall pretty awesome.

After picking my mom up from a l o n g cross country flight from NY one morning, a hearty breakfast was first on her list.  I took a look at what my fellow Yelpers had rated high, and nearby.  Harlow's Cafe came back loud and clear!  

My mom had the super sized, ultra delicious Belgian waffle.  It of course came with butter and maple syrup.  As for myself, I went with the regular stack (5) buttermilk pancakes.  These hotcakes were easily 1" thick if not more!  I always come prepared with a monster appetite, but sadly, I was defeated by the flapjacks in this semi eating challenge.

To sum it all up.  The meals were both giant and delicious, the bill total was under $20, and we left the cafe happy campers.

Some of the best pancakes I've had for a long long time.  nice cozy environment. super friendly staff.  most definitely repeat visitor joint!

"Piece"!!!
Amazing food, diner style, great service, a Tempe-staple and good vibes. Everything you'd want for a small town diner feel.

Dude...breakfast done right.  I ordered huevos rancheros and it came with a side of potatoes.  Delicious.  Very nice and spicy sauce that came with my huevos.

The ladies and I shared a short stack (2 cakes) of blueberry pancakes and smothered it in butter and syrup.  It was sweet and delicious and the cakes were nice and fluffy.

Also, three of the four ladies ordered a side of gravy to go with their biscuits they received with their meals (bread does not come with huevos rancheros).  I sampled a bit of a biscuit and it was really, really good.  Really crisp on the outside and fluffy in the middle.

The diner is small and filled with old-school charm.  There are autographed photos from all kinds of old-school celebrities.  Our server was really sweet and did a nice job of handling all of her tables on a busy Saturday morning.

This place gets four stars just for character.  When you want to go to a place because you know it will be busy then this is it. The eggs benedict was not the best, but good enough that I will eat here again.

I really like Harlow's a lot. I can't speak to the vast majority of the menu, because when I go here it's either for the huevos rancheros or the shredded beef breakfast burrito. Let me tell you, it is difficult to find a good huevos rancheros. There are a couple of other breakfast places I frequent where I have tried many, many things on the menu and love them, but man their huevos rancheros suck. Here, they are perfection. The green sauce is delicious. The beans are delicious. The tortillas are very good. There are eggs, cooked to order, as implied by the "huevos." The service is VERY fast and you pay up front so you can leave at your leisure so this is my go-to breakfast place when I have something to do afterwards.

The food was delicious.  Got a table right away even when it was hoppin!  The servers and staff was incredibly welcoming.  Our server was the nicest server I've had in a long time.  The decor was cute, but overall I just loved the lively atmosphere and vibes of the entire place.  I'd so come back here again if I'm in Tempe again!

Before my trip from Lodi, CA to the Phoenix area, I thought to myself of Foods that I could not find in California that are found here... I came up with Creamed Chipped Beef... maybe it was something of a nostalgic moment... something I haven't had since my Army days WAY back when. Days when the Draft was last used.

As my friend and I drove up to Harlow's limited-space parking lot, we conveniently found the last parking space on the South side of the restaurant. And when we walked in the restaurant was 100% full... but we got the last table available... What luck! Everyone that came in after us, and there were quite a few, had to wait...

On the menu...

Chipped Beef on Toast (**** $9.50) 2/3rds of the Oval Plate consisted of the Chipped Beef mixed with White Gravy concoction. The rest of the plate consisted of a side of Potatoes (**** 1/2), which was Excellent.

Value is not very good on this Entree... as you travel further East in the United States... Chipped Beef will get less expensive.... prices are $4.00 to $6.00 in the East and Southern part of the US.

The dish has the ubiquitous description in the Armed Services of SOS... "S--- on a Shingle".

Belgian Waffles (** 1/2 $6.50) A six-inch Waffle, with a dab of Butter off to the side, with a small plastic container of Maple Syrup. Cold, when I did get it, though. Reminded me of an Eggo... that hadn't been toasted enough. I've never had an Eggo... but it reminded me of one. That's the price, I guess, of popularity - too many orders at one time in the kitchen...

Ice Tea (*** 1/2 ???) Unlimited Refills... but in a smaller-than-average glass... and then you'd have to wait for the waitress for the refill...

Value (**) When I was here this past weekend, most of the customers were ASU Students and a "regular" elderly population. I really do not understand this restaurant's popularity. Average in Quality Food at best, and prices that are $1.00 to $4.00 MORE than you would pay at another basic Breakfast joint. Also... you have to deal with the less-than-average Elbow Room space.

If I think Harlow's is over-priced, how can ASU students afford this place?

Harlow's makes an attempt at a nostalgic recreation of a diner during the depression-era (not the current depression, but 1936) with photographs of it's namesake Jean Harlow, WC Fields, Mae West, et al. Take me back all the way... 5cent Coffee, and meals for a Quarter... now, that's nostalgia! The atmosphere seems more like a Dive than anything nostalgic.

Waitress was personable and conversant, but review is just based on the FOOD!

Pretty good food, but customer service is slacking. Called today to place a to-go order and was told, "we're not doing that today..." A few days ago they immediately hung-up on me before I could even say Hello. It seems like the workers there don't care about customers, unless they are dining in.

Yelp guided us there. A very nice cozy Mom & Pop kind of place. Excellent for breakfast! Service was quick and efficient with smiles too. Really enjoyed the whole experience!

  I had the Gary Cooper breakfast and the wife had the Belgium  Sandwich. My only nit noy about the place was the hash browns could have been more brown!

Went here this morning with a couple of my best friends, all of us long time Tempe residents. Had the Parisian omelette - as tasty as I remember! Crispy home fries were on point too. Still my favorite breakfast place in town, great food and a hometown atmosphere. Nice!!!

Been coming here for some time now for breakfast when we're in Tempe on the weekends. Service is always good, along with the food. Sometimes there's a bit of a wait to be seated, however it's worth the wait.

Besides, it's the only place I know of where you can find chipped beef in Tempe.

Breakfast and Dinner seem like the only meals we get to squeeze into our crazy schedule. Harlow's is definitely a great place in Tempe to get good breakfast. With a very "homey" vibe, Harlow's had a huge selection of breakfast and lunch all at very reasonable prices. 

The place was fairly packed, but we were seated pretty quickly. The staff greeted us with a smile, and we have to say, they were pretty easy on the eyes. Water was already at the table and drinks were brought out right away. We don't think you can order anything bad here. The standard eggs, sausage, bacon, and pancake breakfast was as good as anywhere else. And the biscuits and gravy were massive with plenty of gravy. 

A great local spot to go to the next day after a gig, with plenty of regulars you might have met the night before. A breakfast place that we will be returning to.

This place is a dive!  My husband and I tried it for the first time this morning and the food was TERRIBLE!  The only thing we received that was hot was the coffee.  I ordered a glass of water, coffee and eggs Benedict.  First the water tasted like it came directly from the tap, not at all filtered, the Benedict  was mildly warm along with cold "hash browns" (these are really chopped potatoes with no seasoning).  My husband ordered iced tea, corned beef hash with hash browns, sourdough bread and a pancake on the side.  His tea tasted like lipton, nothing special and all of his food was barely warm.  The toast was so cold the butter didn't even melt, I could not believe that the waitresses that walked by did not say something.  The pancake tasted like it came out of a box and the corned beef hash was straight from a can.  I do not understand how this place is still in business.  The prices are way to high for the poor quality of food that is served, we paid over $30 and I left feeling like I had food poisoning.  We will never return!!  If anyone is looking for a good HOT breakfast check out Biscuits on Elliott and 48th St on the West end of the Safeway parking lot or The Nosh on Warner and 48th St.

Whenever I am taking someone to brunch I automatically take them here. My guy friends love this place because they think all the waitresses are hot but I just like this place because the food rocks and the atmosphere is chill. My favorite item is the chile beef burro? I don't know what it's called but that is the item. I'm not a very big person but I couldn't stop eating it and ended up finishing the whole thing!

"Harlow's"!!! (in Tempe) voted top "Hangover" foods". and holding several awards for best food places for a few years now, this place it's always busy but worth the wait. Their hashbrowns are to die for! and I always get their breakfast burrito, YUMM!!! My mouth waters. I wish I had a picture of this.

If you're a protein and starch kind of gal or guy, this is your place! Harlow's serves up hearty portions, cooked to perfection, in a quirky multi-retro environment.  

We tried to eat here some time ago, but that was around 10 A.M. on a Saturday. Seeing that there was a crowd waiting for a table outside, and that there was no parking in the lot whatsoever, we abandoned all hope and ate somewhere else for breakfast. Fast forward to today- a crisp, sunny Saturday at 7 A.M. We figured not many people would be getting breakfast this early, so we headed over, hoping that the 2nd time is the charm!

There were only 2 or 3 other people in the restaurant when we arrived, but more trickled in as the morning progressed. The interior is a mix of '70s old paneled wood walls juxtaposed with aged posters of various old time movie stars, such as Errol Flynn and Mae West. 

The menu is similarly designed, with a variety of different traditional breakfast items named after classic movie stars. They do have a section devoted to more Southwestern cuisine though, which is what we ended up ordering. I had the Maximillian. It was a large heaping portion of perfectly grilled potatoes, green chile, with a circle of fluffy, scrambled eggs and spicy salsa on top (No sour cream on request). It was such a hefty meal I could only finish half.

Service was friendly and lightning quick. It seemed like only minutes after we ordered, we received our food. Drinks were refilled as needed.

If you can get here early enough, breakfast is a very pleasant experience. I'm not so sure I'd venture here when it gets super busy though!

This place is not too bad but nothing very special. If you're looking for a decent, quick place to eat, try Harlows. The staff is VERY friendly and the service is quick. I was in and out within 15 minutes. The buttermilk pancakes were above average but the bacon was pretty bad. Don't recommend the bacon. Also the location is easy to find in Tempe. Not too shabby but there's better restaurants out there.

Fun mom and pop breakfast joint with old-school Mel's Diner charm.  Huge menu.  All of the carb-laden, glucose spiking breakfast goodness that one craves.  Plus lots of preparations of eggs.  And vegetarian items.  And the kind of breakfast stuff that my grandma would make, like chipped beef.  Bottomless refills of coffee.  Good service.  Good sized portions of food, you won't walk away hungry.  Super reasonable prices.  Definitely a keeper.

I had to laugh when I read Lester C's review, short but to the point and shows that sometimes, the best review is concise and I think he captures the main point, definitely a breakfast place worth checking out.

It is, in all senses of the word, an old fashioned diner. The wood paneling of the interior is from another error and not a design you would see from a place that has been remodeled, I would think, in the last 20+ years but that adds to the rustic charm. The menu is a mix of traditional breakfast foods, many from before the time we worried too much about heart disease (includes me, I'm a huge fan of the Tom Mix, which is corned beef hash, eggs, country fried potatoes and toast) and they have some great Southwest based breakfast items.

From the discussion between patrons and waiters I got the sense that the place has A LOT of regulars and the discussions provide a homey feel that I found enjoyable. I actually live fairly close so surprised that I have not come here more often (oh wait, not a big fan of breakfast food, that would explain it). I would probably do breakfast here on a Sunday morning and then maybe head over to Cartel Coffee Lab, just down the street for a more high-end coffee drink and a chance to read the Sunday paper of your choice. I feel bad about doing that in Harlow's because it is one of those places that the waitresses make more money via the turnover so I don't think extended lingering would be appreciated but Cartel can fulfill that part of your Sunday morning experience if a little Sunday paper downtime is part of your preferred weekend experience. :-)

I love Harlow's because it's old-school Tempe and no-nonsense. Plus, the servers often wear yoga pants.

The food isn't the freshest -- waffles and biscuits are a bit stale -- but it's a perfectly acceptable greasy spoon with a massive menu. 

I plan to return for the huevos rancheros.

We've gone here twice and had the same salad both times. Awesome salad with a ton of warm chicken and a boiled egg.  I give the salad five stars but have not tried anything else yet. Good service and The food came out quickly and was very fresh.

This has to be one of my favorite places to eat breakfast. A must visit! Love the biscuits and gravy and the creamy chipped beef on toast, although I get it on biscuits. Very cute and friendly waitresses.
I wish I knew how to make pancakes that fluffy and deliscious.The service is great and the food is fantastic ! This is a must go to place.

We came here based on a couple of recommendations. When we walked in no one greeted us they just looked at us. The place was old and dumpy looking. Finally a lady grabbed a couple menus and just walked away without saying anything. We followed, assuming she was seating us. She slide the menus onto the table and walked away again, squeezing between us. It was extremely rude and awkward. We sat down, and gave our drink order to the asking server. Upon opening our menu we didn't see a lot of meals, more like separate items. It was odd. In addition, the prices seemed outrageous; $9 for two eggs and a couple pieces of bacon!? That's ridiculous! $8 for a couple pieces of French toast!? After seeing the crazy prices, along with the disrespectful hostess, we weren't impressed, we left. Instead we went to Mill Ave right down the street and had an amazing breakfast at the NCOUNTER.

Seriously the best damn huevos rancheros in the valley. Get them with salsa, it is so spicy and delicious, and the hashbrowns.. Forget about it!  I went today for breakfast. 37 minutes round trip. Awesome.

As per the usual.  This place should have a ten star. The quevos rancheros is expert. I sat  and watched the cooks pumping out meal after meal of excellence. The cooks are the heart of this place. I hope they get paid what their worth.  There should be a tip jar just for the cooks.

Hung over? Come here . 
Hungry as hell? Come here. 
Miss your mom or grandma's southern home cooking? Come here... 
With the rise of all these corporate breakfast and lunch places piping up that are a dime a dozen ... Harlows is still king for breakfast in the valley. I swear their southern gravey cures hangovers.. Be ready for a bit of a wait its pooular with the ash crowd. But this tempe staple is worth it. One bite and you forget you are in a crowded restaraunt and you will swear your eating breakfast on a porch over looking a ranch!

Love comin' to Harlow's!

My favorite dishes are the Cisco (french toast, eggs, bacon/sausage) and Pancho (same thing except pancakes instead). Both are served super fast, taste great with their never burnt coffee, and is not way too much food--the perfect amount after a long Friday night (they even sell Gatorade for after those really, really long nights).

Parking is right out front and along the side of the building (non-covered) up against a Circle K on the corner of Hardy and University. Although the place is usually packed on weekend mornings, finding a spot isn't too tough.

The building itself reminds of what I would imagine Tempe was like before all of the modern infrastructure was built (i.e. huge ASU apartment buildings, stadium, probably anything built past early 90's) which is pretty cool. I feel cozy here when I eat which is not really a feeling I get at other places like nCounter (which is still an excellent place in its own regard).
I like this place for breakfast. Friendly service, cute decor.

Food was so so, nothing special.Prices are ridiculous, really off the chart.The best thing about this place was our very attentive server Taylor.She made the visit worth the trip from Queen Creek.  The BEST breakfast place imo is SAN TAN CAFE on San Tan Blvd. Family-owned and operated. Ask for Kelly and tell her Debbie and Bobby recommended it.Barry is the owner, from Connecticut  ( New Yorker myself) so he knows great food. As far as Harlows... not worth the trip.

The outside of the restaurant is not what brings you in. I'm glad we listened to the yelp reviews because the food was great. I had the Parisian omelet and it was great. The toast was cold and not very good. The potatoes were great too. My son had a waffle and he thought it was ok, a bit boring and wished it came with strawberries or some other topping. My girls had bacon and eggs and thought they were good. One had a banana nut muffin and the other had a peaches and cream muffin. They raved over their muffins and thought they were fantastic.
Comfortable and cozy. Nice place for a perfect breakfast. Staff is super friendly. Has a local feel. The only minus is that the prices are kind of high.

We finally got the chance to eat at Harlow's this past weekend
It was really good
We usually drive by and are intimidated by the people waiting outside and the millions of cars in the parking lot
We got there semi-early so we were okay and there was no wait
All of the employees were very nice and friendly
I got the corned beef and hash
Because thats really the only breakfast option I always get, anywhere
I also got coffee

The food was really good. The corn beef was cooked well and it had great favor
It also came with potatoes which were also yummy
The toast was so-so, I don't care much for toast
The over-medium eggs were fabulous

Everyone should try this place

Good Breakfast Spot! I had a fat plate of what essentially is Huevos Rancheros with Green Chile and Chorizo. The service was exceptional however the food came out "too quick", like, one minute after ordering. Not sure if there is a firing line in the kitchen but wow.... There's always that "WTF" thought in your head when it hits your table moments after the coffee. Regardless, I enjoyed the meal, the staff is friendly and on it. I would come back!

This place has been in my bookmarks for quite some time now so when I found myself hungry & in Tempe I thought I'd give it a try.. not that great

Old school diner with a small parking lot close to Mill Ave.. service was great hostess handed me a menu and I sat at the counter.. waitress cane by right away and brought me water. 

Prices seemed kinda high for the old school diner but hey it's Tempe and not a chain .. 

I ordered the cheese omelet with bacon, mushroom, green chilis and cheddar.. omelet was good, but all the green chilis were in one area and the cheese was a slice of cheese melted on top.. weird .. 

The potatoes were brown on top but not cooked through and there was no salt on them.. a potatoes best friend is salt.. two bites and I left that alone

The biscuits were 2"x2" tall squares .. they were very dense not light and flaky.. I needed a water refill just to get through one of those .. flavor was blah so you definitely need butter & jelly for flavor ..

Now I can cross them off the bookmark list .. probably won't be back
Good breakfast and good service. Very fulling portions. Very big!

This Texas girl was in need of a good Mexican Breakfast so I used Yelp and found Harlow's!  Had the special "Manny's Machaca."  Good stuff "mang"

Service was fast, food hot and yummy, orange juice was ice cold.  Parking was a little tough or I'd have given the place 5 stars.

Had lunch at Harlow's cafe ... ordered the Reuben sandwich and fries.  It was good but nothing memorable.  Service was really good and the staff was friendly!!  Parking was an issue ... next door businesses had signs indicating cars parked in their spaces would be towed.

Wonderful hometown diner. Great basic food and a whole lot of locals are here. I sat at the counter as I was a party of one today. Service was quick and friendly as would be expected in this homey kind of place. 
I ordered the chorizo and eggs. The chorizo was clearly of a high quality. Really good flavor and no greasy fattiness. I was very happy. Came with country potatoes (again, not greasy) and biscuits. 

This is a great place for breakfast if you want to get out of the chain restaurant rut...

I am aware that is this place is a very popular, local "greasy spoon" type of a place, but there just wasn't anything special about the place that made it stand out to me.  The prices were quite a bit higher than what I expected for such a tiny breakfast cafe.  This was discouraging to me.  I ordered the corn-beef hash, which was quite good... actually saving the rating for this place a bit.  I could tell all the food was prepared well.  The service also saved the rating a bit.  We had great service and the place was getting rather busy.  As much as it pains me to say it, I would have been just as happy going to Denny's and getting something off their 4$ menu.

Since moving to AZ last summer, I have been on a never ending quest to find a true breakfast joint/diner. After reading reviews of Harlow's, I was excited to check it out! Unfortunately, it didn't live up to the hype. The eggs were cooked well, but the chorizo tasted off. The hash browns were unseasoned and seemed as though they hailed from a bag of frozen mashed potatoes. The orange juice, which had been promised to be excellent, was nothing more than a hybrid between Tang and Sunny D. Needless to say, I was less than impressed.

Aside from the food (which is the main component at any eatery), the service was quick and friendly and the ambiance, inviting. If you're heading to Harlow's for coffee, toast and somewhere to read the paper or do homework, it's perfect.

Dirty, greasy, and cramped... yet the place is oddly pretty trendy and popular. The waitresses are really hot. The food is pretty good, but it's greasy and fairly typical. Hearty portions served at least... you won't go hungry here. 

If you live nearby, it's probably your best bet... if you have to drive a bit to get here, you would probably be better off with some place in your neighborhood instead.
Me and my love this place!  I like the old feel and the food is good.   You have options!

Very good breakfast!  We shared the Western Omelette & Beligum waffle with a side of fresh strawberries, coffee & tea. The food & service was very good, the tables were clean & the prices were fine. We'd definitely return.
The water and coffee tasted like mold. The banana muffin was mediocre, I wouldn't recommend it. The side of 2 over medium eggs were cooked perfectly.
Breakfast all day. Healthy portions.  Tiny diner but food was very fast.   No substitutions and no Amex.

Love this place, major problem is that there is always a wait on the weekend and no reservations.  My other knock is that they have some crazy pricing-while some items are certainly reasonable such as a side pork chop for $4.75 how can you justify $4.00 for a side of cottage cheese.  Breakfast is fairly old school but with a lot of nice specialties.

My Husband and I were in town for Spring Training - GO A'S! 
Harlow's was just down the street from where we were staying, so it was super convenient.  So convenient, we ate there the three mornings we were in town.
The breakfast menu is large with many options. 
The french toast, pancakes, egg sandwich and homemade chorizo are off the hook.  The homefries, not so much.  I found them to be a bit bland tasting.   I just asked for them to be well done, which helped a little.
The service was pleasant and fast.
The place was busy every day, so my guess is it's a local favorite and I understand why.
Harlow's is the best diner in Tempe. Amazing eggs benedict, friendly staff, and fast service. Extremely underrated.

So I hate breakfast let me start there. I consider myself a foodie but there are so many things I won't eat..bananas, avocados...but most importantly eggs and breakfast. 

Now since you have got past my first section you must still be relatively interested on how I can give Harlow's 5 Stars when its a breakfast spot. First off the tradition. Harlow's has been a staple in Tempe for years. It looks something you would find in the woods and is super welcoming. Also for the guys out there not only is the food great but a majority of the support staff is also excellent. 

Now this place does get slammed so be prepared for a potential wait. I have only gone during the week with clients and at the most its been 5-10 minutes. Since I don't like most breakfast food I also go with the corned beef hash or the green chile burrito. They are both amazing and you leave not only feeling full but prepared for an afternoon nap. 

All in all you NEED to try Harlows you won't regret it.

Got food poisoning here today. I have been here before and have been satisfied. Today though I got the biscuits and gravy with eggs. Since then I have been vomiting all day. Very upset this is keeping me in the house on a Saturday
This place was close to my house so I thought I'd give it a shot. The food is okay,  not bad,  it just didn't leave me wanting more.  Service was good and the atmopshere is typical diner.
Great little Cafe. Friendly fast service. Great Chorizo burrito! Very flavorful. French toast was yummy too. Would highly recommend. Will return.

I was looking for a good diner, went to trusty Yelp, found Harlow's, sorted by Elite...Mark D's review had me at "bad girl." 

Looks like Harlow's could be a good impromptu UYE lunch spot or hangover recovery HQ. 

I had the basic eggs scrambled with cheese, home fries with onions, wheat toast. My diner standard fare. Good stuff, just what you're looking for when you need the diner grub. 

Harlow's is pricier than diners I'm accustomed to. $7 is a little steep for what I had. But it was perfectly diner-done and in front of me in under 5 minutes. When I lived in Cleveland's west side there was a large diner density so to stay competitive they always had specials for under $5 bucks.

My friends took me here for breakfast while I was visiting them this weekend. We went on Sunday morning around 8:30. We waited for a seat about 10 minutes. Once seated we were greeted right away. Service was very quick and friendly. I had the eggs benedict. The Hollandaise was tangy just like I like it. I didn't care for the ham on it, it was smoked with a strong flavor. Overall it was good but I also wish the breakfast potatoes had more crunch to them, they needed to be browned longer.

This is a special place, but not because the food is amazing.  The food is adequate, and frankly perfect for the multitudes of hung-over Tempe bar hoppers.  The menu is large, and there are items on the menu that are great, and some not so great. 

For example (great):

Read the other Yelp reviews, people seem to concur that the Huevos Rancheros is where it's at.

I personally like their traditional 2 egg breakfast.  There is Cholula on the table, and the food is done right.

For Example (not great):

If you are there for lunch, and a BLT sounds good, order ANYTHING else.  The BLT is a skinny little slice of a sandwich on wonderbread.  Nothing cool.  (Go to Wildflower Bread Company if you want a BLT done right).

Why this place is special:

In the early days it was called May West, and a despute over the name resulted in the renaming to Harlow's.  In both cases the diner is "Early Hollywood" themed-- Starlettes and old movie posters line the walls.  

The dining experience is down-home, and small-town-ish, which is something Tempe used to have a whole lot more of-- charm.

So, this place is special because it is charming, relaxing, and full of good old fashioned comfort food in the old Tempe tradition.

Old school diner that is still on point. Anything Mexican will have some kick to it so if you like spicy then make sure you try the Eggs Maximilian with Chorizo... Service is quick when you come as a small group (4-6 people). I tend to stick to traditional breakfast items but always end up eating something else. I like this place as its keep to it's core without having to expand and appeal to the masses. For those not wanting the chain breakfast restaurants, a good place to come. For others, step outside of the box just a bit and give it a shot.

Went on a Saturday morning, and it was packed...that was a good sign!  Although it was packed, we only had to wait 10 mins for the 3 of us.  I had the Eggs Maximilian with chorizo...wow...what a huge meal for $10.  I was pretty well nourished for the remainder of the day.  Full of flavor since it had everything but the kitchen sink in it.

Service was fast and friendly...drinks never got below 1/2.

Will definitely be back!!!

Visiting from out of town and our can driver recommended Harlows for a good, cheap breakfast. I was a little skeptical at first but was pleasantly surprised. Delicious food, very kind staff, and extremely speedy service. The huevos rancheros was prime! Definitely recommend!
A great little breakfast place close to asu. Don't be intimidated by the shady exterior. Commit and get a good drunk recovery meal!

The best breakfast in Tempe.  Is that not enough?  How about the most friendly wait staff?  Still not enough?  How about mid west small town charm and decour?  Jesus... okay how about... the best cup of coffee and some of the best salsa, WHICH YOU CAN BUY AND TAKE HOME, in Arizona.  Get their early or be prepared to have a twenty minute wait.

I remember these guys when it was May West over on McClintock. Anyway, I dropped in here the other day and it is absolutely old school perfection. Every item I have ever ordered here has been above par and the servers go out of their way to make sure you are taken care of. FYI - It gets pretty crowded at peak times.
Great little "greasy spoon" breakfast diner.  Usually packed if you get there to late in the morning though, especially weekends.  Great omelettes and super service!

Love this place. The waitresses are amazing and the food is quick and yummy !!sometimes on the weekends a bit of a wait but it never takes too long. It is a family feel atmosphere and you just don't find these breakfast places anymore . I recommend this to everyone
Great local spot with good food and service.  I would definitely  go back.  My wife and I love small hole in the wall places to eat.  Give it a try... You'll  love it.

Pros:
Quick seating (the place was packed and our party of seven was seated within 10 minutes)
Friendly staff
Quick service

Cons:
Food won't bowl you over with flavor
Parking is a nightmare
Best place for breakfast in Tempe! Best biscuits and gravy hands down, and their peach muffins are amazing!

A good find.  Dropped in on a Sunday and knew I was going to like it right away.  Good crowd, from the loner elderly man to the families, to the younger college types.  The selection is great, the prices are right (a little note on that later) and the ambiance is...cute.  I hate saying cute, but it's cute.  The service is fast and polite.
As for food, great.  I got the creamed chipped beef and was super happy.
The one bad was I got a fried egg for the top and it punched 2.75 on to my bill...which is ridiculous.  Almost 3 bucks for one egg?  Was it a unicorn egg?

All in all, stick to the menu and you're golden.  I'll be back.  :)

All the servers are super friendly, if not just a little hungover usually. But hey. Who cares. Food comes out super fast. Prices are great. Food is awesome. Chorizo burrito is killer, so are all the waffles and pancakes. Huge extensive menu can be overwhelming to a first timer. They have simple things too like the wild bill. And they have grapefruit juice. Winner. I hit harlows about once every couple of weeks and love it to death. fresh, fast, affordable and tasty. Cool atmosphere too.

I always turn to yelp when exploring a new place I've never been. It was my first time visiting Tempe, AZ. I thought to myself, "Where is everybody?" Driving around on the road in the middle of the day, it was 90 degrees out and there weren't that many people out. Then I went into Harlow's for brunch due to yelp recommendations and realized everyone was here. LOL But really, I think everyone is indoors when it's hot out. The food here was phenomenal, I had the eggs benedict. Perfect taste and perfect portion. This is how all eggs benedict should be. My boyfriend enjoyed his meal as well (biscuits and gravy)  and the service was great.

This place is pretty much a Tempe institution. I didn't go to ASU, so I don't know if it is a college thing or only popular with the working crowd, but it IS popular. Parking is a challenge and the place is not fancy, but I've never been disappointed in the breakfast. The Eggs Maximilian and Huevos Rancheros are some of my favorites. 

I've never found the coffee to be anything spectacular, but it is kept hot and full, which is nice.

The staff are consistently friendly and service is good. Although it slows down a little as the place fills up, there are usually plenty of servers available to handle the crowd and they turn over tables pretty fast at breakfast time. During lunch, it seems that people tend to linger a bit longer, so the wait is likely to reflect that. There's no inside waiting area, so you either get seated quickly, awkwardly hang out by the register or go outside. I think I've always gotten a seat pretty fast.

It is good, simple food that is made well and served up pretty fast, too.

Sometimes Yelp reviews are insanely out of touch with reality. I had to do a review after seeing this restaurant has over 4 stars. It was dirty, dark, the service was bad, children screaming everywhere, and the adults present were not much better and just as loud as the crying babies. The food was worse than what I'd make at home if I was in a hurry on a weekday morning. It wasn't expensive, but we still left regretful about having spent money on a disappointing experience. I guess if you want to sit in a booth with ripped seats in the food crumbs of the person who ate before you, or you are just too hungover to care, then umm maybe? The amount of stars this restaurant has is one of the mysteries of the universe. I just don't get it.

Before I ate here for the first time, I had read the reviews on Yelp. When my friends said it was that awesome, I decided to try it out. It's not bad but I didn't think anything was incredibly outstanding. It's a good place to stop if you want breakfast that isn't too expensive and isn't in a regular chain but if you're looking for out-of-the world, this may not be it.
Fast, friendly service. We always have our meal within 15 minutes or less after ordering. Absolutely love the food. I've yet to try their lunch but their breakfast is amazing! This place is the best.

Great food as usual... went on a Monday at 10:30am, we had the green chili burro, 2 pancakes & the maximilian breakfast. The OJ is fresh and so dang good. Coffee strong and good too. Waitresses are always super nice and friendly- very much a locals spot (a nice juxtaposition to the Mill Ave Tempe vibe) - go if you haven't yet and are looking for great breakfast food
I was bummed that there were no substitutions, and you can't split the checks. The food was good though.

I drove by this place dozens of times not really knowing what it was about, though I assumed it was some kind of restaurant. A steak place? Who knew, but there were always lots of cars...

So I finally gave it a try, and I've drug lots of people back many times since. It's an old school cowboy diner, more or less. HUGE breakfast plates that include all the standard American classics with some Southwestern faves as well (chrorizo, huevos rancheros, green chile breakfast burritos, etc). Every massive plate comes with a big steak knife on top to help you cut your way through all the goodness. For the portions, the fresh ingredients, and the atmosphere, it's a $7-8 breakfast which is a real deal.
Love this local spot in Tempe! Its cozy, clean, fast service with friendly servers it's my favorite weekend breakfast spot. I love they have corned beef hash!
Decent , American food, hot locals and fast service. Came here for brunch and would come again if Essence Bakery isn't open.
Charming relaxed atmosphere (converted house), great coffee and sandwiches. Love the local artist work on the walls.

We stumbled upon this little gem due to its proximity to our hotel while staying in Tempe.  The food was fast and tasty and the service was excellent. The portions were hearty and prices reasonable.  They apparently have daily specials which we didn't try, but looked good and were reasonably prices.  While I usually try as many places as possible when in a new city, we did go back for a second trip on our way out of town.

Been meaning to try this out for sometime now and had the opportunity yesterday.  Had the traditional breakfast and the potatoes were nothing to write home about.  My company had the cobb salad and it was not impressive at all.  Service was very good but I don't think I'll be coming back.
Tried Harlow's again today. The green chili burro breakfast and biscuits and gravy are very bland. The side of blueberry pancakes was excellent. Note to Harlow's: wash your filthy, grimy front door !

If you're looking for a fine dining experience this is not the place for you. That being said, I love going here if I want a cheap, hearty, and greasy breakfast. I have to agree with some other reviewers, it does take some salt and pepper for flavor, but still good.

Drive by to see a packed parking lot every weekend. I decided to see for myself what was happening here. 
I always order something simple when I first visit a restaurant, if that's not good, chances are neither is anything else.
So..... coffee- not great, but I am used to the expertise of cartels...
Hash browns- boring, bland
2 eggs over medium- yolks hard.
I rest my case... will not return. People were nice, the place has a down home feel, but if you going for the food...

I can't believe how poor the food was this Sunday Morning. This used to be one of the very best places to have a great breakfast at a great price served by the most beautiful coeds ASU has to offer. Well the waitress's are still eye candy but I don't expect we will ever return. 
The food came very fast..impressively fast but it was all cold. I ordered a Green Chilli Burro and I swear it was Hormell Chilli right out of the can and didn't even resemble anything like a green chilli.
 The Biscuts & Gravy were also cold. The biscut was more akin to a dinner roll and the gravy had no taste.
What a shame. I hate it when landmark resturants cut corners.

My girlfriend was wanting a place to get pancakes at a place that was low key and not overly priced.  She used Yelp to find a place near by.  This was the first time we visited.  

I use a scoring system that is based off a 1-5 scale with a 3 meeting expectations.  I do a category score for the food, staff, and venue.  The total average score is reflected in the yelp review stars

TOTAL SCORE-3.35

FOOD-3.3
5-Service / Speed 
3.5-Overall Taste
2-Plating / Look
4-Menu Variety
2-Cost

STAFF-4
4.5-Attentiveness
3-Look
4-Friendliness
4.5-Menu knowledge

VENUE-2.75
2-Atmosphere
3-Cleanliness
3-Location
3-Feel

Oh Harlow's... you messed up by getting rid of your cooks. First of all, you currently do not have the same cooks as you did for the last 20 years so please update your website. You need to find a way to make peace with your old cooks, bring them back, and pay them more! Cut corners somewhere else, but definitely not with your cooks. We waited 30 minutes for traditional breakfast when we use to wait literally less than 5. The quality of the food sucked! It really did. I'm sorry, but it use to be 100% better. My scrambled eggs were so scrambled and chopped up, there was nothing to them. I have never ate a piece of egg as small as a piece of cereal. The potatoes were raw, mushy, and not flavorful or crispy like in the past. My biscuit was dry, not fluffy, and tasted old. We noticed several other tables with practically full plates, as it seems many others were dissatisfied. One good thing was our server Taylor. She informed us straight up that there would be a longer wait as the kitchen was backed up. It was nice of her to give us a heads up, but we are regulars and knew wait times have never been before so I look up and notice new cooks who looked lost and a stack of pending orders lined up waiting.  Get your shit together! We will not be back ever again unless the old cooks are there popping plates out hot and fresh. Your business is sinking in the mud and you will not be able to recover if you don't make changes quick. Denny's is above you at the moment, what does that say? Very disappointed and I know I wasn't the only one, so soon I'm afraid you won't have any customers. Please Please bring back your old cooks as they rocked the house.
Another great brunch at Harlow. I love their corned beef and hash. Always made perfectly.

Today was our first visit to Harlow's. This review is some constructive criticism for the owner. The service is fantastic, food is very tasty (even though my over easy eggs were cooked through) however the coffee is burnt and everything is way over priced. For lower cost you can get better quality ingredients at The Normal Diner or US Egg. For example real cream for coffee and real butter for toast. Paper products instead of styrofoam. $10 for two eggs and potatoes, $3 for what taste like old burnt coffee... It's a bit much to swallow. I'll come back if prices lower or quality improves.

Harlow's Caf is like that longtime friend you can't figure out why you stopped hanging out with.  Maybe it's because you were lured away by fancy brunch places with 90 min wait times but then you realize, all you needed was Harlow's.

We came here for breakfast on a Saturday morning and were seated right away at 9 AM.  This place is a traditional, old school diner so you get a table, a booth, or counter service.  The Boy order The Maximilian and said it was amazing.  The Portion was HUGE and he ended up taking the rest home.  I opted for the half order of biscuits and gravy which comes with a choice of meat.  We also split a short stack of pancakes (get off my back, we were on vacation) which were fluffy and almost a  1/2 in thick!  Sorry no photos, we were too busy stuffing our faces for me to even think of picking up my camera.  Everything was good, everything was old school, and everything was minus the crazy long wait of the trendy places.

Do yourself a favor.  Go to Harlow's for breakfast and go call your longtime friend.  They both love to hear from you.

I've been a breakfast zombie here for over a decade. Typically was my hangover remedy- a greasy full breakfast with unlimited piping hot black coffee could revive anything! But recently I was in my old neighborhood bright and early, sans hangover and really wanted to stop in..... This place is just as amazing without an alcohol stupor. My belly loved it. The biscuits-Amazing! The refried beans (which go great on everything)-Fantastic! You can't go wrong with any main dish you choose.

So my friend ordered the Eggs Benedict and she did not like it at all.. their Hollandaise sauce was very "lemon-y" and just not good, so we alerted our waitress and asked for 2 eggs over medium instead.  No problem, we got the two eggs as a replacement and ate our meals. 

I had the corned beef hash, which tasted like it was from a can, potatoes which were good, and sausage patties which were excellent.  They easily and happily made my meal sans butter/dairy as requested.

One little bonus was that our server had an ass that was hypnotic... in the words of the great Mr. Pacino, she had a "GRRRREAT ASS!!".... but I digress

When our meal was complete we received the bill and noticed we were charged $10 for the Benedict plate.  "No prob.", I thought, she just forgot to take it off.  It was New Years day and they were swamped up in there.  So I get to the counter and alert the hostess, she goes and speaks to our waitress and returns telling us that our waitress said we ate half of the meal, which is why we were charged.  WTF?!?  I explained that she was wrong and literally two bites were taken... 1 by the person who ordered the meal and 1 by a friend to confirm how gross the dish was.  She ended up removing the item from the bill, but the whole experience left a bad taste in my mouth, so to speak.  We're not some grungy, poor ASU students trying to scam a free dish, fuck off.

Came here for the first time last week and had a pretty good experience. The restaurant itself is cramped and the tables are close... but it feels home-y. First off, coffee was simple but good. Service was great and the food was awesome. I had the Cisco and my boyfriend had the eggs Benedict. Both were delicious.


The decor is also a nice touch. I loved the glass stained window and the decorations on the walls.

Harlow's and me go way back. OK, well, if you consider the mid to late '90s "way back!" when I was more convenient to Tempe. It seemed only natural though, that when we'd done the half marathon this past January...let's go back to Harlow's. 

I like that they have been in the Valley for a long time, family-owned and that they make many items from scratch daily. I like that the food comes fast and hot and that the server, though really slammed on a Sunday morning, still takes the time to chat with you. I like that, when you realize you did a credit card and cash dump (for the race) and you only have a American Express (they take on V and MC) and a $20, that the hostess knows how to handle the situation without making you feel like an idiot. (Because she knows you already do!) 

Thanks, Harlow's, for being a class act...like your namesake.

Yes you will probably have to wait for a table on the weekends. But you'll be grateful you did. When I browsed through the menu, I just couldn't decide on one thing -- so I got three and shared with a friend. We probably could've just had one entree and been perfectly content though. Portions are huge! You won't be disappointed. All made from scratch in house. Worth. The Wait.

This is the go-to breakfast place in Tempe. Everywhere I travel, I always search for these one-of-a-kind, owner-operated restaurants. When I found Harlow's a few years ago, I was not disappointed. Now I eat here at least once per week.

My usual is #2 Cisco which is French Toast. They also have a lot of good Mexican breakfasts. Always check the board for special, like Eggs Maximilian with chorizo. Chorizo is home made.Or Chicken-fried steak and eggs.

Portions sizes are HUGE and often it is my only meal I need for the entire day.

The cooks at Harlow's are the ultimate professionals. They manage to prepare food for dozens or hundreds of customers every day.

The wait staff is exceptional. Friendly, welcoming and always on the ball, re-filling your coffee or iced tea.

Enjoyment of life is all about simple things like finding a good breakfast place with tasty food and friendly people. You will find it at Harlow's Cafe.
Great place for breakfast! It has a Midwest small town feel to it. Parking can be a bit difficult but worth it!

Every time I go, the food is incredible. The service is great! 

For those other reviews: yep, it's diner food. If you're prone to indigestion or other gastric ailments, you may not want the chorizo burro. But there's something for everyone here.

The BF and I went here this morning for breakfast after finding it on yelp. I thought it sounded good and I love trying new places, so we went. The place was busy, we almost left because there were no parking spaces left... luckily we made one more pass and someone was just walking to his car to leave. There was a little bit of a wait, but not bad. So the inside of this place is really cute, with the wood paneling and all. We got a cute little booth. We both ordered coffee, which was very meh. Really watered down coffee and cost 2.25 a cup. For breakfast, I ordered the spanish omelet and the BF got biscuits and gravy. The omelet was really good. It had a kind of spicy sauce on it that was tasty and I added cheddar which really went well with the sauce. The potatoes that it came with were nothing special, no real flavor. It also came with toast which was what it was. That cost 9$. The BF liked his B&G but thought it was a bit salty. It cost around 8$ with bacon. Overall, I'd say the place was good, but not great. For the 27$ I spent after tip, I could have gone to Liberty Market which is much much better, so I probably wouldn't come back here.

This was my choice for  breakfast after asking google for the best breakfast in Tempe. Apparently, google isnt allowed to lie because it was spot on.  When we arrived, the waitress was super quick to attend to us.   She showed us to our table and gave us menus.   She did tell us that it was her first day but i couldnt tell. She seemed like a pro.  I ordered eggs, hashbrowns, toast with bacon.  The food was amazing.   all throughout breakfast the waitress asked if everything was ok.  Food was 10/10 and service was 11/10 .  On a $28 bill i left a $20 tip cuz it was that good.

This place was best summed up by their biscuits. Different than you'd expect, yet still pretty good.

See, when I think old school diner, I expect a crowd of old people and a waitress who has... well, who has been beaten down by life and is still standing out of tenacity and spite. Instead there are young, attractive ladies (a friend called them hangover hotties) serving us, and a mix of young trendy kids and old bikers enjoying the food. 

The coffee was typical diner coffee, maybe a little pricy.

Then the food came. Both my wife and I come from breakfast loving families, so we have high standards. The biscuits were at first disappointing, looking like dinner rolls. But they tasted right, and were actually not bad. The chorizo and egg was definitely gringo style, but some cholula fixed that. The omelette wasn't her dad's omelette, but they were dang generous with the bacon. Beans were good, but the potatoes were like a blank canvas, in need of your ketchup, hot sauce, and salt and pepper accents.

Overall the experience was teetering between 3 stars and 4. It was pretty good overall, but the great service gave me that extra push. They live up to the four star rating.

Slightly hungover and needing something to soak up the alcohol, my lil bro and I walked to Harlow's from our hotel. Chorizo burrito burro and coffee were just the things to get the job done! I loved the homemade salsa that came with the burrito. It had the perfect amount of spice. There were a lot of other things on the item that I would try if I were to return! The ambiance was also great - this place could definitely be featured on DDD.

I had juuuust sat down when the waitress asked if I was ready to order and immediately had an attitude with me. No exaggeration, just sat down. After I said no, she came back about 2 minutes later asking me again. Another lady working there informed that the kitchen was closing shortly. That's certainly understandable. It was the way it was done that was really off putting.

Plenty of food coupled w/ fast/friendly service makes this place worth the stop. I tried the biscuits and gravy, scrambled eggs, sausage and hash browns -- healthy heart fo sho!  Half order of biscuits and gravy took up a dinner plate, as did the side of hash browns, and i could only eat half of each. As for the taste, i found the gravy a little on the bland side, and the biscuits were about the same.  Potatoes were pretty good, kind of a cross between hash browns and home fries. Eggs and sausage were alright.  Server was cheerful and buzzing about, making sure refills and requests were met. Lastly, a good-sized crowd by 0715 on a Saturday.  All in all, a decent bfast.

Cheers!
RS

A couple of friends and I had the pleasure of coming here for breakfast after this year's Pat Tillman run. They had been previously, but I had never heard of it. What a nice, little surprise! As other reviewers mentioned, Harlow's gets crowded and this was especially true after the race. But despite that, they got us seated within 15 minutes. Not too shabby. Service was prompt including the water and coffee for our weary and parched souls. 

I had the Cisco, I think it was called, with french toast, two eggs, and sausage links. I have had better french toast elsewhere, but I still really enjoyed my meal. My companions also had meals that looked delicious. Perhaps even more so than mine? Can you say food envy? Anyways, the prices were average and also the ambience. I can see the charm of an unchanged place after many years especially when you have been coming for years. Overall, I thought it was cool. Would I drive from CenPho for the food? No. But I would stop for breakfast if in the area. I am glad I had the chance to try it....

Came here on a Thursday morning during a business trip and it was rather awesome!It had a dive-y feel to it.. like it's been around forever...

Ordered the corn beef hash w/ scrambled eggs, potato and biscuit.

The corn beef hash was pretty good!! 
The scramble eggs were a little too cooked
The potatoes under seasoned
Biscuits weren't fluffy

Notes: They don't separate checks but they do let you charge 2 credit cards.

=)

Harlow's is awesome! We have been coming here since before our kids were born. It's a delicious weekend morning habit and now our children, 8 & 5, have it too. The food is always done well, especially huevos rancheros and pancakes. The service is always friendly. Never been disappointed.
Frankly, it's okay if you aren't particular. A little too crowded, a little too greasy. If you want pancakes for breakfast and don't want to make them or go to IHOP, you could do worse.

I have probably driven past this place hundreds of times and never noticed it.  It's a restaurant that is a converted trailer.  The inside is a lot larger than you'd expect.  Nothing fancy with the decor, it's got the feel of an old-timey maybe a little bit grimey diner.  It was packed on the morning we came, so we knew the food would be good.  My friend and I both enjoyed our food.  However, it was a little too busy for my taste.  We felt like we were rushing in and rushing out to make room for the other patrons.  Since it was a Saturday morning we would have preferred a more relaxed environment where we would feel comfortable to sit and relax.

I had the Gary cooper with a biscuit. My boyfriend had the same with a banana nut muffin. We were seated and served quick. I was really impressed. My server was attentive and polite. I enjoyed my first experience here. The food was all fresh and homemade. I wish I would have gotten the banana muffin, it was to die for.

This is a Tempe classic. If you're looking for a good home cooked  breakfast meal this is your spot! I've been going to Harlow's since my younger days living in Arizona with my family. This place has had the same cook for years and although I don't know him I can tell you his food is made with deliciousness. 
  In regards to staff, the waiters here are always friendly. We've never had to wait long for our food! So honestly what more could you want?!
Thank you Harlows for always a being the go-to place to have a great( and very filling ) breakfast !

Excuse me if I'm a bit scattered but I'm still on a super sugar high from eating Pancakes for lunch.  The carb sleep will be hitting any moment now.  

So I'd never heard of this place really before driving by it the other day.  I meant to Yelp it but forgot and I'm almost glad that I didn't this time.  Pretty much my experience was Bonnie's experience. Well, less tattoos and more jocks, but that's about it.  I really liked the potato's at first, but was really struck that they felt "dry" without the onion and/or peppers.  Ya gotta at LEAST have some onion.  

That said - I'll totally come here again.  When the girlfriend is craving IHOP and I'm craving anything but - we'll come here.  While their lunches looked pretty decent, it's definitely a breakfast place to me based on what I saw coming out of the kitchen.  The waitresses were super nice (Yea, and generally pretty hot.) and totally flirted with the kitchen guys.  And those kitchen guys were totally en fuego!  That food was coming out so fast!  I sat at the counter, old school style, and got  the full show.

The whole place has that comfortable "I think I came here as a kid" feeling even though I've never been here before.  I can tell that everyone else looked just as comfortable.  Yea, it was $8 for my breakfast/lunch, $10 w/ tip, so I won't make it a regular thing, but I'd end up paying that much when she wants IHOP, and the atmosphere and the view (not just the waitresses) is SO much better here it's a bit easier to justify.

Personal tip - Girls you have to check out the bathroom.  Tiny yes, but that wallpaper is freaking amazing!  Totally reminds me of my aunt's old wallpaper sample books from the 70's.  SO cool!

This place is on our list of must stops during our annual Spring Training Trip. Nothing better than a hearty breakfast from Harlow's in the morning after a late night on Mill. Potatoes were awesome, biscuits and gravy off the chart. The portions are more than you'll need too. They totally can accommodate large groups too.
Great little place.  Lived here my whole life and have never been.  Love the food.
I love this place. Always busy and always tasty! I keep telling myself to go back but the wait is crazy I wish they had more tables.

There's something oddly charming about this place. My 2nd experience happened this past weekend - Sunday breakfast at 10 a.m. As I pulled up in my car, I could tell the place was quite popular. I sensed a wait list. I walked in, put down my name and took a seat outside on of their benches. The wait wasn't long - perhaps 5 minutes - and I was shortly shown to my table for two. Few minutes later, my Breakest Buddy showed up. We had concluded to call this "brunch" since it was a compromise between breakfast and lunch time. In any case, breakfast foods were on the mind and my belly was ready. 

Coffee first, please. 

The waitress, you could tell, was rather busy. I didn't mind that, but I did mind her spilling my coffee each time she poured more. Her rush wasn't coupled with friendly pauses, and I felt like I was more of an inconvenience than a patron. In any case, we ordered "brunch" and chatted it up. It's not every day I roll out of bed before 10 a.m. on the weekend. This was a special occassion; one well worth it. But, sadly, not because of the breakfast. 

The eggs were rubbery and the muffin was hard to swallow without honey. The cottage cheese was good, but how can you screw up that? Yes, I ordered the Hot Body Breakfast. So sue me. My friend ordered panckakes with eggs and bacon. Only half was eaten. 

You know, there's something oddly charming about this place. It's a warm cafe, reminiscient of a small town mom & pop establishment. It probably is, and the fact that it's thrown near ASU makes it the preferred after-hang over joint. I can see how rubbery eggs and greasy pork would suit one's belly after a booze fest. But, it's not ideal for the belly without a drop of liquor coating the stomach lining. 

I used the bathroom, too. Talk about a tiny walkway stuffed with clutter, like high chairs and cordless vacuums. Again, it's charming in a home-for-breakfast kind of way. 

It almost reminds me of Shortcakes. Almost, although Shortcakes is in a train car and has, let's face it, the best after bar and in-the-mood-for-cheap-food appeal. Sadly, it's back near OSU in Stillwater. I miss Shortcakes. 

Harlow's wasn't memorable to me. That's probably why I've only been here twice in my life.

Sidebar: I wouldn't call this place "cheap." With plates averaging around 8-10$, that's quite the purse punch that should be met with some delicious raves and reviews. Sadly, to me, it's not worth the moolah.

Harlow's is great! Whenever I'm on a long layover at Sky Harbor I take the 10 minute cab ride to get a quick bite. You can expect classic, fill-you-up, diner style breakfast. The staff is quick, friendly, and keep your coffee cup full. 

I had the B&G which was good. Their biscuits are corn-breadish which was interesting but it worked. Haven't had a meal here that hasn't been good. 

Harlow's isn't exactly the most innovative cuisine, but they do their thing well and it's worth checking out.

I use to eat here all the time, because the food was delicious and I did not mind paying $10 for a delicious and stacked meal. 

But I came here yesterday, after 3 months, and it had completely changed. My Huevos Rancheros literally had a small streak of green chile, my potatoes weren't crispy (instead, they were just boiled and put on the griddle for less than a minute, and they were still scorched with no oil), and the beans tasted old. Not to mention, the plate also down graded in size. 

I was sooo embarrassed, because I had brought some people from out of town to enjoy my favorite breakfast place and it was a big disappointment. My friend ordered the biscuits and gravy but it had little to no meat and was very bland!!

The only reason I am giving this restaurant 2 stars is because of the service. My coffee just never seems to run low and I love it. The waitresses are always on top of their game.

I want to know what happened to this place, and if these changes did occur, they need to be fixed. I understand about the portion sizes, but the quality of the food should still be there and I strongly urge them to reconsider their lead cooks if they're putting food out like this.......
just wasn't impressed.  i had heard good things about harlows but the food was not noteworthy, the prices werent' great for what you got and the waitress was a little rude

Movie themed in decor, with lots of booths, and overall is a throw back to a casual diner 40+ years ago.  Traditional breakfast favorites.  Nothing we had was bad, but nothing great either.  Worth trying.

Tried this place after seeing all the good reviews. Let me start by saying,  the place is packed, seems to have a good steady stream of local clientele comming here. I ordered french toast and let me say...the food was delicious, eggs were nicely cooked,  french toast was puffy and tasty, and the bacon and ham are off the hook. The one Negative is the server, didn't know her name, she was a tall blonde girl with glasses early 20's. she wasn't very friendly, didn't even look at us when we were ordering, wasn't very welcoming. Then at the end of the day while talking to the table next to us she stretches out her arm and slaps are bill on the corner of our table without ever comming to our table, just extending her arm. From the next table and slapping the bill on our table, no "when your ready" or "thanks for comming " no contact at all, I understand it's busy, but cmon.  Food is fantastic, but very poor service from our server.

The food was amazing but, a super inconvenience that they can't split checks. You're in the customer service industry and dividing payments is a huge part of that. The fact that it's such a hassle makes me second guess coming here. You need to upgrade your payment method to accommodate you're customers. Other than that service was good!

Been to Harlow quite a few times. It's a Tempe Institution. The food is consistent and I dig the location.

I personally love their Eggs Benedict and the Vanilla coffee creamer. I know to some that's pretty lame, but a good Hollandaise and a delicious creamer can be hard to come by!

I won't prattle on in this review. If you live in Tempe you'll make it in here at some point. Relax, enjoy a homey breakfast and leave satisfied.

P.S. I've heard great things about the Chorizo and Heuvos Rancheros ; )

what can I say about this place? it's amazing. it's delicious. it's about damn near the best breakfast place i've been too in a while. My server, olivia was her name, i believe? idk, doesn't matter. green haired cutie took my order and even gave me great life advice on how to properly take care of turtles. like who does that? she does. she's amazing. if you see her, tell her she's an amazing server. and deserves a raise.

We were sat fairly quickly considering the fact that it was a Saturday morning and the place looked crowded. The space we sat on was a little small so be expected to be cramped in as the cafe is tiny. The food was decent but I got the eggs and canadian bacon so typical breakfast plate. Overall, ok price, ok presentation but the service is quick which is great! My first time at Harlow was not that great as I ordered food I did not like but this second time around, I liked it much better.

I thought the place was charming and I liked the hometown feel.  Neat story about how this is a family business and there was a contest for the new name of the restaurant.  Would be nice to know more about exactly what that contest was.  Was it Harlow the 1965 movie?  Not sure.  

The food was great, the service was great. The coffee was not so great, minus one star.  

Still, all was enjoyable.  I will go back, but might bring my own coffee.

This is my favorite breakfast spot in the Tempe/Phoenix area. Close to ASU and it shows by the multitude of ASU fans that are always inside and the ASU paraphernalia that lines the walls. The breakfast food is amazing and I would highly recommend the eggs maximillian with chorizo. Their coffee is amazing and the servers are very friendly. Five stars!

Visiting Arizona for the first time and wanted pancakes along with great coffee . I found it at Harlow's Cafe . Excellent service and the food was delicious. Definitely would be coming back if I'm ever in the area again ..

My husband and I have eaten breakfast here a dozen times and we have never been disappointed.  Their food is consistently good.  Their coffee and bakery items are also excellent.  My hubby always orders the eggs and chorizo with a side of refried beans.  He say they make it just right.  I have ordered a variety of items from the menu and I have always liked everything that I ordered.  I really appreciate the fact that they have some options on the menu that are not so large that you can't finish them or feel stuffed.

The place is always crowded on the weekends but I have noticed that if you go earlier in the morning it is less so.  Also, when ASU is not in session it is a little better.  Just be prepared to wait for a table and don't come with a large group of people or small kids.  On the flip side, I appreciate the fact that after you are seated and enjoying your meal, the wait staff always takes your order and brings your food and coffee refills promptly but never makes you feel rushed or gives the impression that they are trying to turn the table quickly.

Small diner spot. Gets busy on weekends and the small parking lot fills up. Food and service were great. Typical diner breakfast spot which is nice bc there aren't a ton in this part of Tempe. I'd go back!

I've driven by here a lot, and recently we had friends visit from out of town so we hit this place before the zoo. There wasn't a huge crowd, so we got seats quickly. The food was standard but totally yummy and a good price. :)
